Hi all, in case anyone would like to read entire the "Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time" book by Jeff Sutherland but don't want to buy the book on Amazon, you can borrow it off your local library using Libby or Overdrive for free! Here are easy 4 steps on how to do so:

1.	Register for a Boston Public Library eCard - <https://www.bpl.org/ecard/>. It’s free to anyone with an address in MA.
2.	Sign up for an Overdrive account here –  <https://www.overdrive.com/media/1678411/scrum> OR download the Libby app on iOS /Android - <https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/libby-by-overdrive/id1076402606?mt=8>.
3.	Link your Libby/Overdrive account to your Boston Public Library eCard, and now you can borrow ebooks and audiobooks for free! As mentioned above, the Scrum book by Jeff Sutherland is available at BPL. The audiobook is narrated by JJ Sutherland and I quite like it.
4.	If you want to view the book on your laptop, on the app Libby on your phone, go to the ebook you’ve borrowed on your shelf, and click “Send to Kindle”. Then, download the Kindle for PC/Mac program, log in, and you should be all set!

If anyone has any questions do let me know! I’m a big fan of Libby/Overdrive and am happy to troubleshoot.

The partial shutdown of the federal government is starting to affect air travel as a growing number of security agents are refusing to work for no pay.So far, however, the impact on air travelers has been relatively limited with no significant disruptions. But airport workers and travelers are concerned that conditions will worsen if the impasse continues, throwing travel into <http://turmoil.At|turmoil.At> least one airport, Miami International Airport, will start closing one terminal early each day, starting on Saturday, because of a shortage of screeners employed by the Transportation Security Administration, said Greg Chin, an airport spokesman.

Data on house disbursements for 2018 in quarter 2.
This output shows all the food and beverage transactions of over $10,000. Only four large events qualified over the period covered in the dataset.
I chose to look at all the expenses made by the Chief of Administration. This program has filtered for that subset of data
Congressman Capuano expenses over 1000 dollars.  This csv provides oversight of the local Congressman's expenditures.
This is all the franked mail expenditures in excess of $1000. If actually investigating this, I would sort and rank members to explore hypotheses about who sends the most franked mail.
This filters the cosumption ammount of printing and reproduction more than 1000 dollars
# This file seeks to identify all expenditure in food and beverage above 100 dollars by the US House of Representatives
This new program looks at gasoline expenditures over 100 dollars. The goal is to see if certain offices are paying significantly more for gas expenses as a proxy for positive constituent service.

This CSV file contains congressional expenditures whose purposes included the phrase "carpet" and that exceeded $500 in the first quarter of 2017. There are 26 such transactions, most of which were made by either the Chief Administrative Officer of the House or by the Furnishings Office.
This subset of data represents rows where someone has made payment to policy advisor for more than $10,000. Turned out that very few members did aside from the committee on budget.

Each quarter, we budget about $20 million for our congressional chiefs of staff. If you are looking for a chief of staff role in the future, the economic prospects look like they can vary by quite a wide margin. 105 amounts paid were for $935 in the quarter. I would hope that these are biweekly paychecks, but this would seem to hover right around the poverty line. On the other hand, 66 people were paid $41,167 for the quarter which would lend itself to a nice salary. Also, if you are looking for a chief of staff position, it would appear that Nancy Pelosi would be the place to start -- she had twice the payments compared to the speaker of the house, Paul Ryan! (Although more analysis can be done to see if these may be due to accounting rather than personnel differences).

We will simplify and expand access to income-based repayment so that no student loan borrowers ever have to pay more than they can afford. Democrats will also fight for a student borrower bill of rights to ensure borrowers get adequate information about options to avoid or get out of delinquency or default. Finally, Democrats will restore the prior standard in bankruptcy law to allow borrowers with student loans to be able to discharge their debts in bankruptcy as a measure of last resort. To make progress toward these goals, the government should offer a moratorium on student loan payments to all federal loan borrowers so they have the time and get the resources they need to consolidate their loans, enroll in income-based repayment programs, and take advantage of opportunities to reduce monthly payments and fees."

Unemployment Data:

The dataset MAPC 2012-2016 Labor Force (Census Tracts) was downloaded from Massachusetts Area Planning Council’s DataCommon (<https://datacommon.mapc.org/browser/datasets/128>). We edited the file to include only columns: census tract number (column name in original: ct10_id, column name in final: ID) and percent unemployed (column name in original: unemp_p, column name in final: unemployed). We changed the CSV file to an excel file. Using the merged file containing Opportunity Zone census tract and town names, we used a VLOOKUP function to identify which census tract was an opportunity zone and filtered out non-opportunity zones, and merged in town name (column name in final: Town). We removed the first “25” from each census track.

The MA average unemployment (6.8%) was obtained from the United States Census Bureau’s FactFinder page (<https://factfinder.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/index.xhtml>). We searched for Massachusetts in the “Community Facts” search bar, clicked on “Income” on the left-hand navigation bar, clicked on “Employment Status (Age, Race, Sex, Poverty, Disability, Education, …)”, and clicked on “2016” in the Version menu. The 2016 version is the same time period as our 2012-2016 MAPC data.

Data cleaning: We removed census tract 25001014100 from Forestdale and 25025980101 from Winthrop due to poor quality or missing data.

The Opportunity Zone Program was created as part of the U.S. Tax Cut and Jobs Act of 2017 to incentivize investment in low income communities. State governors can nominate up to 25% of their state’s low income census tracts to be deemed Opportunity Zones. Capital gains from investment in economic activities in Opportunity Zones are given favorable tax treatment through the program. The program presents an opportunity for both Opportunity Zone residents and private investors to benefit from these incentivized private investments.

Gini Table 1

The U.S. Tax Cut and Jobs Act of 2017 created the Opportunity Zone Program to provide incentives for investment in low income communities throughout the country. An Opportunity Zone is a designated geographic area, in which individuals can gain favorable tax treatment on their capital gains, by investing those funds (through a privately-created Opportunity Fund) into economic activities in the area. The U.S. Treasury has designated 138 tracts in 79 Massachusetts communities as Opportunity Zones. The Opportunity Zone program presents an opportunity for private, tax-advantaged investment into areas of economic need, benefiting both residents living in the zones and private investors. Governor Charlie Baker announced the designations on May 18, 2018.

Some of the Massachusetts opportunity zones certified by the U.S. Department of the Treasury have left locals scratching their heads over why an incentive is needed to build. While low-income parts of Fall River, Springfield and New Bedford made the cut, so did neighborhoods in places like the tourist-heavy Provincetown as well as Alewife in West Cambridge, which developers are already building up as a life science relief valve to Kendall Square.

Hey team, wanted to share my initial idea for a data set--I thought it might be interesting to look at Opportunity Zones (the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 created a program where certain new investments into economically distressed communities would get preferential tax treatment).  This is still fairly recent so there's not a ton of data out there, but I have been able to find a dataset with all of the census tracts that were nominated and are eligible (<https://www.cdfifund.gov/Pages/Opportunity-Zones.aspx>).  I thought this could be represented as a map comparing the number / percentage in different states or could even be done at a city level (e.g., comparing the number between cities).  Am not yet super invested in this specific idea, so welcome any and all feedback!

So I just reviewed the requirements and the only thing I could find that we *didn’t* do was make a README file for each graphic that we put on our site.

From Dhrumil:
Your Dataset

We’re not going to have a proper “back end” server that pulls from a database and serves up an API. Rather, you will find a dataset and place it in a folder within your repository.

For each dataset you should have:

a copy of the original data in the format you got it in
a README.md or README.txt file with a link to the original data source and an explanation about how you transformed the original data into the final format you needed. If you’ve done the transformation using a python script, just uplaod that script (no need to document). If you used some other means, please document your data transformation process in the README file. It should be a step by step explanation, not just one pithy sentence like “I transformed the data with excel”.
a copy of the final data which will be consumed by the visualization
Remember, sometimes you might be able to tell a better story by filtering the data down to an interesting subset rather than visualizing all of it.

I think agile sounds amazing, especially when compared to waterfall. If you're going to end up with a crappy product, you might as well get to it faster and improve on it. I think in the private sector world, I could imagine this style being excruciating though. In the user story meetings, I would imagine companies would want the biggest possible problems solved in each meeting. Then if mismanaged, every daily scrum meeting would be a chance to show your inefficiency, and every retrospective/sprint review could be a deadline to work all night to finish deliverables for an artificial deadline. Just thinking about it, it seems like a dystopian nightmare that a capitalist would love.

However, in government, this might be the best process. Government contractors surely can get overworked, but I would be surprised if any of them are working 100 hour weeks in usual circumstances. And government agencies that I've worked with are usually wow-ed by small incremental improvements. Suddenly the dystopia starts seeming more manageable and collaborative. I think this is where agile should live, and this is probably how you can start making bigger gains. That said, government agencies are notoriously slow to change, and agile seems will require just as many to changes to ageny perspective as it will for procurement processes. One can hope that more waterfall disasters and agile successes will slowly move the needle for more efficient and helpful governments.

I heard some feedback that agile & SCRUM seemed like a lot of overhead work for this class--but I think that actually highlights exactly what SCRUM is supposed to provide. SCRUM commits us upfront to a significant investment in communication and management that yield savings over the life of the project. It's not a great fit for a short, 2-week project that is unlikely to face major scope and schedule drift, precisely because the project is too short and low-risk to yield much savings in schedule slippage.

Basically--yes, it's a lot of meetings and can feel like a lot of overhead. But that's nothing compared to public-sector norms of quarterly meetings where nobody does anything substantive for 2.5 months and then scrambles some half-assed work together in the last couple weeks before the meeting. Daily meetings take a lot more "overhead" time than quarterly, but that investment is well worth keeping constant tabs on schedule and scope (and, frankly, helping prevent those occasional weeks in the nonprofit/public world when you just zone out and don't get much done and nobody really notices, because there's no regular followup).

Furthermore, without daily meetings I don't think the agile process would work at all. Without that constant daily communication, we wouldn't be able to make tasks independent and doable in parallel. For quarterly or even monthly meeting approaches, we would very likely need to fall back on waterfall methods to make sure each team doesn't pursue long dead-ends of incompatible workflows in between the monthly followups. These are the management takeaways that I think can scale into physical businesses (like transit authorities), beyond software development.

Agile seems to works well when we have something that requires functionality. The same principles of failing early and iterate, might also work when we do not know what is causing the problem. In public policy often times the root causes of problems are highly politicized and often times do not reflect reality. For example, the way to balance a budget often times is not to cut taxes. So these principles could work outside of the software development space to create an evidence-based appproach to better understanding problems.

In economics there is this new concept that people are studying which is the collapse of the elasticity of trade. Prior to 2007 world trade tended to grow at double the real growth rate. such that if the US economy grew at 2% its trade tended to grow at 4%, that rule held up for most economies. This rule of thumb collapsed as of that date no one really knows what it happened but people believe that part of it is explained through the measurement of good and services in trade. A great deal of it now happens electronically, especially services, and we are not counting it.

So after finishing Aaron Schwartz’s short book and reflecting on Chapter 8 “Conclusion: A Semantic Web?“, I’ve come to an impasse in my thinking that I can’t seem to resolve. On the one hand, I do believe in the *idea* of a semantic (openly-connected) web in the same way I believe in dismantling trade barriers and tariffs in the international economy: It is a nice theory but not practical in the real-world.

On the other hand, I do not want a completely fee-for-service web where each site hoards its data, requires subscriptions for access and tolls for traveling by…

Instead, I believe these two extremes represent the nodes on a continuum of which the openness of the web is a point on the distribution. And that point on the distribution is not static, but rather is constantly changing depending on laws, regulations and the political climate!

For instance, under the Trump Administration and Chairman Pai of the FCC, we have moved away from Net Neutrality and may be moving increasingly towards the anti-Aaron Schwartz position.

Any thoughts from anyone on my supposition on a *dynamic political culture of the internet* and *where we are now on the continuum*? Would love to get some feedback on this train of thought…

Agile is best used for projects that are complex and highly interrelated like the visualization project. High level of iteration allows enough failure early enough in order to identify problems. This allows one to solve the projects. The user stories allow the project to shift from a “get it done” mentality to a “is it useful for the client” mentality. The “poker” aspect of the scrum is also useful to allocate the work to the people who can do it the most easily some team members may do somethings very well and some others not as much.

Reading through Sutherland's book on why he founded Scrum was interesting to me. It brought me back to my days as a management consultant. In one of our projects, we had too many people involved with no clear, quick way to keep track of the deliverables. One of the consultants introduced SCRUM to the leadership team, including only the top 7 people leading each team to provide very quick headlines on their progress and the roadblocks.

Ultimately, SCRUM didn't hold up to our expectations. As <@UF19DNZ5E> mentioned, it is difficult to implement SCRUM on monumental size projects. In total, we had over 150 people working on the project, and to narrow it down to just 7 people for frequent, daily meetings meant that these 7 people spent their entire days obtaining updates from their staff, however small. They did not trust leaders from other teams, hence the stand-up meetings simply became somewhat of a pissing contest. Saying nothing would have been terribly embarrassing and nobody wants to talk about their roadblocks. This was in Southeast Asia, where "saving one's face" is commonly important.

As mentioned by my other classmates, I wonder if SCRUM has a place in large scale projects, and in areas where cultures where trust is not the norm. I'm only halfway through the book and am still reading up more material, so I hope I will be convinced otherwise by the end of this class!

Really enjoyed this set of readings. Two strains of thought came to mind, both related to personal career experiences. First off, these readings have continually reinforced how my first job at IBM in IT project management was largely learning an obsolete craft. For two years, we were ingrained to employ the waterfall method and consistently valued documentation and project tracking over actually getting the software done right by creating user value. We slowly started to do some things to shift towards agile lite like deploying automated testing and breaking the massive phased projects into smaller chunks that were somewhat "Sprint" like. Still, a valuable experience to learn the pitfalls of a failed approach (which were demonstrated by our constant project delays and client tension. Second, the readings made me think about my own effort this summer in Chicago to promote a "US Digital Service Model" for Chicago's City Government. Serving as an intern in the Mayor's Office, we were each tasked with proposing a New Idea as part of annual competition. I had read about the US Digital Service Model and a similar version at the city level in Austin, TX and decided to proposed replicating it Chicago. It was interesting how the turf war nature of Chicago's city government immediately disliked the idea of IT folks coming in and messing with traditional lines of authority. By the end of the summer, I was able to make some progress in encouraging the idea, but it demonstrated the difficulty in pitching "good ideas" with proven results, especially when they cause disruption in the status quo.
Edited for clarity.

I wonder how much Agile and Scrum have been explored in other sectors and what the results have been. A good example is that of R&D grants. Granting agencies like NSF or DoE traditionally grant resources to R&D projects based on a waterfall approach. The R&D process is one of information discovery, meaning that at the onset of a project, the outcomes could be predicted but not guaranteed. On top of that, an R&D project can reveal new information that is not known before the grant was awarded but that merits pursuing new and different activities. Researchers and granting agencies could benefit highly from adopting an agile framework in which grants are approved based on scientific merit of a team and the general ideas they want to pursue. Progress can be reviewed in sprints and rather than having a complete project described at the onset, the activities could flow with the newly acquired information to areas that show higher promise for breakthrough or innovation.

I was particularly moved by The Atlantic article about <http://Healthcare.gov|Healthcare.gov>. At the risk of sounding too idealistic/naïve (which Sam appropriately addresses above), I was pretty excited to think about this team of coders tackling such a massive and important system and ultimately being able to cut the cost of building the system by $256 million and the cost of annual maintenance by $69 million. I wish I could understand coding better just so I can get a more technical understanding of their approach. How did this team know where to even begin when they opened the login page and identified glitches?
The part about the team having to wait to get a security review on AWS really resonated with me as someone who worked in federal contracting before coming to HKS. Deadlines often get pushed further and further into the future for project components that in theory shouldn’t be a source of stress, which can be frustrating. This relates to a topic that I would love to have the speakers’ take on: there seems to be so many “blockers” to implementing significant change in government systems- from budgeting to deep-seated silos to outdated procurement to overall skepticism. What would the speakers say are major barriers to applying scrum in the public sector that one wouldn’t typically see in the private sector, and how do they envision overcoming them using Scrum techniques? In the second Scrum reading, one of the barriers, skepticism, was raised, but the solution was glossed over. I imagine this is a major issue in the public sector, but also an inconsistent one. I wonder if the speakers have any experience/successes with overcoming it that they could share.

I agree with many of the questions raised, here are a few of my thoughts from the readings:
- I’d love to learn about what agile looks like in non-tech environments or with teams that aren’t creating a software product. Echoing Danny’s question, I’m looking forward to hearing from our speakers about how to successfully implement agile and scrum in the context of a more hierarchical/traditional organization.
- In “Elements of Scrum”, I loved learning about determining the relative amount of work each task will require. It seems like a way of allocating time and effort that is so intuitive, I might apply it to my own to do lists.
- In reading the <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> articles, one mentioned the failure of opening the website to everyone at once instead of starting with a small circle to get feedback, iterate, and expand to more people over time. While starting small and iterating seems to be the way to get a good working product, in the context of a government service, how do you decide who gets first access in an equitable manner? Is it unfair to offer it to some, but not others? Alternatively, this may be irrelevant if we set up the roll out to be transparent about who will get access and when.

Many policymakers are painfully unaware of how data can be used to advance their policy goals in a more targeted way to better serve constituents. Even slow and cumbersome systems like at the FBI can prevent organizational missions from being completed successfully. In my personal experience, government technology systems lag behind those of private firms, and for some obvious reasons (like funding). But if improving technology improves the functionality of government, then technology enhancements should be a top priority for governments.

A question to our guest speakers: what are the main barriers to productivity or effectiveness in your experience in government? What are some specific ways we can apply the agile/scrum mindset to overcome obstacles to flow in our teams? And, given that not everyone on a team will have experience working in scrum, what methods should we use to change the mindset of our teams? I don’t want to rely too much on training, but at the same time, these processes only work if everyone buys in. So, especially if we are not the team manager, how do we promote buy in and collaboration around this approach?

It also seems like there are tradeoffs between getting work done as quickly as possible and doing it right, even if it takes slightly longer. It makes sense that most teams have areas where efficiency can be improved, but in some cases the teams are working as fast as can be reasonably expected. As a manager, what tools can be used to identify the point at which efficiencies are being maximized, without crossing over into the space where errors are being made?

Scrum/Agile is definitely a thought provoking approach to team management.  I worry a bit that there may be a false dichotomy between a more agile approach and a waterfall method.  Here are a few of the concerns I came up with:
-Scalability.  Its not clear to me how scrums would work on monumental size projects.  Communication between hierarchical or peer scrums is not facilitated.  This could result in teams independently "re-inventing the wheel" to solve the same or similar problems.  Additionally, Scrum's heavy reliance on trust would make it very hard to incorporate into big organizations.  Similarly, self organizing teams seems unlikely in some of these institutions.
-Story choice aggregation.  The increasingly short nature of sprints makes the focus more and more on small user choices.  For instance, Facebook programmers might be looking at a user story in which the user desires some convenience at a small cost of privacy.  This story may be perfectly fine in the individual case, but as the same choice is repeated you can end up in a place you never expected.
-Similarly, some choices and priorities are inherently more likely to "win" out over time.  For instance, a story about user convenience is likely relatively straightforward and easily quantifiable (some period of time saved).  A story about privacy is likely to be much more convoluted and more difficult to break into bite sized pieces.  Thus by the Scrum methodology, the convenience story is likely to continuously rise to the top of the list while privacy remains at the bottom as a bigger, more nebulous story.  This is true of other concepts such as autonomy (freedom) vs safety or security.
-Organized labor.  I've been trying to conceptualize what a Scrum environment would look like in an industry with strong unions.  Haven't come up with anything yet.

This isn't intended to be overly negative towards the Agile process, it has many advantages.  Is there a way to combine the advantages of a Scrum-like approach with those from Waterfall planning?

In thinking about the readings this weekend, something that struck me is that the issue of making change in government is something that is widespread and not limited to the tech sphere. Some of this likely has to do with the rigid structure in which government departments operate, which makes me wonder: how can we change government as a whole to keep up with the changing demands of the 21st century?

In reading the articles about <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> from Time, The Atlantic, et al, I was struck by what seemed to me like a mismatch between one of the central principles of agile—customer collaboration—and the way the articles discuss the coders as sort of distant, superhuman, all-powerful code magicians (e.g. the Time article calls them “tech wizards” and alludes to Gabriel Burt’s background in rocket science). That isn’t to say that the folks who got <http://healthcare.gov|healthcare.gov> working weren’t very smart or talented, but it seems like the agile ideal would be to have them integrated more smoothly into the government’s infrastructure, able to collaborate with non-coder colleagues on a day-to-day basis. Granted, a lot of the mystique here might be media-created and not reflective of the on-the-ground experience of government employees who worked with the coders, but it still seems like scrum has a bit of an image problem. I wonder what teams using scrum methods can do to overcome programming's mystique and appear more approachable for non-coder stakeholders, since it won’t do much good for coders to want to collaborate if the non-coders are hesitant to do so.

Some stories in the reading were very interesting.  Other digital HKS courses, such as Product Management, Digital Government, and Future Issues in Cyber-Security Policy also mentioned about differences between waterfall and agile. It is very interesting to find that the FBI could have linked information about 9/11 in advance if there was a better computer system. Similarly, projects that failed due to waterfall were mentioned in various ways. (f-35 fighter jet development failure) But I wonder how a specific case was specifically planned based on waterfall and what the plan was looked like. And it would be interesting if there's an analysis about how such case could be designed in an agile format.

The reading started with the traditional waterfall method that operates project step by step, and makes sure each step works well and led to the result. Whereas the Scrum is taking the working process as a holistic process. Question: the efficiency about scrum. Because of its working principal, Scrum is frequently deliver with small changes, but how could these indirect mix-up steps can help clients who don’t really have professional skills understand its value when it’s on early stages.

Also found the readings very enjoyable. I have 3 questions in mind. 1) Flexible processes sound good but where does the overall budgeting comes in? Particularly for projects such as government ones that require annual budgeting, how does the method estimate long-term budget beyond identified sprint work?  2) How do teams balance releasing minimal viable products and limiting vulnerability against cyber security threats etc? Again, I am curious about government projects that require extra caution and face critical scrutiny (and where people love "control and predictability" and less tolerant about failures). 3) Scrum members have total authority over how the work gets done and seem to have lots of discretion. How does the team ensure continuity if  a team member left unexpectedly, given that there is no detailed documentation?

My initial thoughts after the readings are basically centered around agile vs waterfall and if agile is adoptable in non-tech environments. In my experience, it is not completely useless to have pre-defined goals, expectations and deadlines. I am curious to hear how agile methodologies have been received and adopted in traditionally bureaucratic spaces and how fast (or not?) it was to get people efficiently working with them.

The Wired article on the USDS mentions uncertainty about the future of the agency a few times. Particularly because this article was written in the summer of 2016 (prior to the US presidential election), I was curious how the Trump administration had impacted the USDS. However, this really highlights for me the additional challenges of making change of this kind in government, where beyond the usual culture struggles there is a broader layer of political ideology that could be very complex to navigate. Curious to see what our speakers have to say about this!
Learning a specific methodology like Scrum is really helping me understand how the agile methodology can be applied.

From the reading scrum, the scrum team member are encouraged to be the self-mange and high-performance work, so these characters seems to be the open system with a group of flexible members to finish the work together. And the joke about “a chicken and a pig” try to indicate the members in the scrum team are committed to the work rather than finish it. I have two questions about it,

Q1: Think about the “assembly line” of Ford company in 1913, the way of workers just need to focus on their own part of work, it’s more like to finish it rather than commit the work. The advantage of the assembly line is efficiency. It is obvious that the scrum team is not assembly line but with the high efficiency. How does it work, is that also means the way of assembly line is out of date?

Q2: Since the scrum is an open system, how to guarantee the information security between a lot of different cooperation especially in government project need to be confidential.

So the reading was awesome! Loved learning about how to improve processes and how that has impacted teams ranging from the FBI to Toyota. I also liked the synergies between the two texts and how Jeff Sutherland was the author of one and the subject of another. I'm honestly pretty excited to start working with this methodology as opposed to the traditional waterfall approach. I've had the experience of sitting in an office building being lectured about my "TPS Report"-like document (thank you Office Space) so I'd love to turn those processes on their head and actually work in a way way that is *effective*.

Hi all. I have one question about agile as it pertains to government organizations--do you think an agile approach could potentially allow for security risks by bringing in a wider array of participants? 18f would seem to open the door for a lot of people (perhaps with no security clearance) to be highly involved in producing government platforms, etc.

To be a bit more specific -- The Wired piece (on the Obama tech surge) seems to mock fears of a flexible, parachute-in approach to fixing problems. Do you think these concerns are valid at all?

Excerpt:
"Judging from the focus of a recent hearingheld by the House Oversight and Government Reform IT Subcommittee, one might think that the most pressing issue in government tech was not saving money and delivering services effectively, but making sure that the Chief Information Officer (CIO) in a given agency has total reign over his or her domain (Congress had recently passed a law granting agency CIOs more authority). Will Hurd, the subcommittee chair, frettedd that USDS people might “parachute into an agency, and fix things, without the knowledge of the CIO.”
“But the calls for “accountability” from this nascent effort seem out of proportion to the tiny investment that the USDS represents. In fact, these demands seem very much a part of the risk-averse culture that led us to the current mess in government IT.”

I'm still reflecting on the Scrum readings, but a few initial thoughts and questions:
-One aspect I feel like most of the readings glossed over was how the "gathering requirements" step is much faster or more efficient using Agile methodologies or Scrums.  Wouldn't you still need to do the legwork of understanding basic requirements and creating User Stories?  How long does this take?  What makes it fundamentally faster than the same step in the Waterfall?  My understanding is that it leads to efficiencies down the line as you only prioritize what is truly needed, but in order to do that, don't you still need to build this basic foundation of requirements?
-I'm curious about how the contract negotiation and expectation setting works using this model.  I thought the readings made great points about the added bureaucracy, difficulty in sticking to predetermined milestones, and frequent cost overruns using the Waterfall method.  But it also highlighted the skepticism that stakeholders may have towards the limited information an agile team would be able to provide at the offset of a project.  It looks like most agile teams are able to build trust with stakeholders over time through constant interaction and early delivery of working products, but how do they get over the first hurdle?  How have these teams been able to avoid the pitfalls of the Waterfall approach and structure more efficient contracts while also managing  their stakeholders' expectations?
-Echoing some of the sentiments brought up in class, even after the readings I have a keen sense that using Scrum teams must be predicated on having a really strong and motivated team.  Based on my own experience working across a couple of different sectors, I really have a hard time visualizing this working in many non-tech environments.  I would be really curious to hear successful cases of where this has worked beyond technology development
-As a bit of an aside, I was a bit surprised by the harsh treatment "Scrum: The Art of Doing Work in Half the Time" gave to Gantt Charts.  While it's likely not the best way to plan projects, I've seen them used very successfully in general project planning (though I may be biased given my background--in my former life as a consultant and when working with non-profits, setting clear project plans, deadlines, and expectations were essential).  This relates to my previous point in that I'm still a bit skeptical of how well this approach works in other contexts

The Elements of Scrum reading offered a side by side comparison of a waterfall approach compared to an agile approach, imagining two teams working to complete the same assignment, and in the hypothetical, the agile team is able to return revenue in the second quarter. Understanding that this is just an imagined scenario, and that the reading didn't describe what the software was actually meant to do, I don't understand how the agile team would be returning revenue on a half-finished product? As I understood the agile reading, the iterative process allows the agile team to create a product to test and adapt, but that's not the same as immediately putting an untested, unfinished product into the market. How would this work?
Thanks for the response. I will definitely ask him when he comes.

One question I have after doing the readings is: “how can different scrum teams collaborate?” And, relatedly, “how do you adapt scrum when you fail to meet the two pizza rule?”

In our class (section b), we have groups that are 4 people and an overall group with 16 people. We are using scrum for both groups, but one group is smaller than recommended and one is larger - in our small group, we haven’t designated a project owner, scrum master, etc. which seems appropriate for the timeframe, but have other groups tried to put in additional structures? In the overall class, we will still have standup with all 16 people, but would it make more sense to designate one person per group to talk about how the class is working for that group’s learning goals? Is there a way that scrum structures can cascade upwards easily?

Alternatively, or in addition, should there be a way in which scrum groups dialogue about what is working or share their learnings with the greater team. I would worry that scrum could supplant silo-ing by work type with silo-ing by scrum team/project if implemented in a rigid way. How do we overcome these potential issues?

import csv
with open('veggies.csv','r') as f:
	reader = csv.DictReader(f)
	rows = list(reader)

#Group by color
veggies_by_color={}
for row in rows:
 	color = row['color']
 	if color in veggies_by_color:
 		veggies_by_color[color].append(row)
 	else:
 		veggies_by_color[color]=[row]




#print to terminal	\
from pprint import pprint
pprint(veggies_by_color)

#output to json
import json
with open('veggies_by_color.json','w') as f:
	json.dump(veggies_by_color,f,indent=2)

For security experts, the main issue they care about is the security condition about AV. They want to know how the general public think about AV so that they could address more focused questions in the future development and modification of AV.

The chart above shows some results from a survey done by Bile Pittsburgh on March 2017 in Pittsburgh, presenting how residents feel about sharing the road with AVs as a bicyclist and/or as a pedestrian.

This particular chart show general public's response towards the question "On a typical day, how safe do you feel sharing the road with human-drive cars/ with Autonomous Vehicles?" . 1 represents "very unsafe" and 5 represents "very safe".

We choose to overlap 2 different results together in one single charts to show how many people answered one certain number for human safety but another certain number for AV safety. I shared this in the general thread, but I'll share with the team as well. I created a google doc as a glossary of all the command terms across languages because I was having a difficult time recalling them in class or during the homework. Feel free to use it and add to it:

As a disaster response agency, I want to understand the connection between climate change and increased frequency of natural disasters so that my agency can create long term plans and budget estimates.

As a company or land developer, I want to be able to see where occurrences of disasters are most frequent so that I can make business decisions with the best information available to me.

As a climate resilience expert, I want to see which regions experience the greatest human loss from each kind of disaster so that I can better target programs and policies to reduce suffering and help communities bounce back from disaster.

As a philanthropist, I want to know where and how often the biggest disasters occur in terms of both human economic loss so that I can prioritize my charitable work and generate the biggest positive impact.

As someone who is skeptical about climate change, I want to see for myself whether or not more natural disasters are occurring over time and whether or not they are increasing in intensity/impact so that I can determine how much I will support efforts to prevent future impacts.

As a federal policy maker I want global benchmarks on disaster impact and disaster response / prevention funding to understand whether the U.S. is underperforming relative to peer countries

As a federal policy maker I want information on historic trends to understand whether disasters are becoming more frequent and/or severe

As a federal policy maker I want information on relative frequency and impact of different types of disasters to appropriately allocate response and prevention funding

As Dima I want to learn how to visualize time series and maps to effectively present social science data in my work and studies

As a climate change activist I want a website with a clear and coherent storyline that addresses the link between climate change and disasters
I mostly focused on one user persona with several needs (seems plausible that one user can have several needs)

My Approach has been topic agnostic, since Jon has done such a terrific job with by looking at User Stories from our topic.

User Stories

1.	As Ruha I want to be able to develop a website with hyperlinks to outside resources and embedded visualizations so that a visitor can get a comprehensive picture of the selected topic.

2.	As a student of DPI 691M, I want to be able to learn from my fellow classmates so that I can internalize the skills being taught in class.

3.	As a news-junkie, I want to visit a website on Topic X which is updated and relevant so that I can be informed with the latest data and trends.

4.	As a Harvard Professor, I want A2’s project to be based on impartial data and objectively analysed so that the public website shows critical, unbiased thinking of policy students.

5.	As a person interested in Topic X, I want original interpretation and refreshing insights, not mere repetition, so that I gain a different perspective on Topic X.

I am a policy maker who wants to understand whether investment in climate change mitigation will help reduce the effects of natural disasters so that I can make informed decisions around appropriations

I am a resident concerned about how climate change affects natural disasters so that I can better understand the risk to my home.

I am a meteorologist interested in understanding the increased risk of natural disasters as a result of climate change so that I can better prepare my constituents/viewers for future climate events.

I am a business owner looking for information about extreme weather events so that I can make an informed decision about investing in weather preparedness.

I am a climate change skeptic looking for a website with a weak narrative or poor data analysis so that I can easily poke holes in its conclusions. (Anti-user story)

Hi Tabinda,
Here are the paragraphs. I imagine that we can hyperlink with html and so each of these links can be embedded in parts of the text:

Climate change can increase wildfire risk in California through its effects on moisture availability, temperature, vector prevalence, and lightning. Several academic papers have linked climate effects by showing that climate change has increased drought in California (<https://www.pnas.org/content/112/13/3931.long>), led to more pine beetle infestations and tree mortality (<http://science.sciencemag.org.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/content/362/6416/758.1>), and augmented the flammability of vegetation that fuels wildfires (<http://tenaya.ucsd.edu/tioga/pdffiles/Westerling_wildfire_jan2008.pdf>). As a result, modelling efforts predict that wildfires will become more frequent and larger throughout the century (<http://tenaya.ucsd.edu/tioga/pdffiles/Westerling_wildfire_jan2008.pdf>).

In addition, separate research has shown lightning strikes in the western United States are will become more frequent in an altered climate, which bodes poorly for California where wildfires are most often ignited by storms (<http://www.atmos.albany.edu/facstaff/vollaro/pubs/Romps.et.al-SCI2014.pdf>). With higher temperatures, fires are expected to rage hotter and lay scourge to more area (<https://blogs.ei.columbia.edu/2014/10/13/what-do-wildfires-have-to-do-with-climate-change/>). For these reasons, normally-cautious scientists have begun to draw a causal link between climate change and forest fire (<https://www.pnas.org/content/113/42/11649>). With large fires in the state over the past few years, the media has joined the frenzy, proclaiming that California is burning and climate change is the cause (<https://www.usatoday.com/pages/interactives/news/california-wildfires-carr-fire-data/>)

Above, we showed that California has gotten dryer and hotter especially in the areas of the Mountains where many of the state’s forests lie. Below we have taken a separate data source to show how those changes have corresponded to fire trends.

Here are some questions to keep in mind when searching for data:
* How have frequency or extent of fires changed?
* How has drought changed?
* How has sea level and flooding changed? How has coastal development changed?
* How have landslides gotten more frequent?
* How are cities dealing with climate-related hazards?
* How much has the state spent on flooding? Has this changed over time? On fire over time?  What about specific cities?

Hi all, so my initial idea was that we could show how the recent election in Brazil changed the climate policy outlook in the country. I thought it would be interesting to visualize Brazil’s climate goals (from their INDC) and show how Bolsonaro’s policies compare. We could break this down by sector and potentially showing how this could affect Amazon forest cover by using Google Earth Engine (which uses Javascript to work with satellite imagery).

Since talking to the team, it seems like it may be better to do something more centered on climate change impacts on the city. We could take a few different case studies (based on what data is available) and try to visualize current and future impacts of climate change. If possible, I would like to try my hand at Google Earth Engine through this project (one of my learning goals), but I think this software could have various applications to a potential project including showing drought, forest cover, and other landscape-level changes.

*Here is what I wrote out about the first idea that I think we will not use*:
* Show how Bolsonaro’s policies could impact the Amazon rainforest
* How that could relate to climate change
* How that could relate to Brazil’s NDC and climate goals (I wrote a memo on Brazil’s NDC and climate goals before Bolsonaro was elected)

Things we need:
* Understanding of previous policy (have this)
* Understanding of his policy (don’t have this)
* Find datasets (don’t have this)
* Start visualizing different sectors and change (don’t have this)

I kept thinking about the possibilities of analyzing the discourse of national leaders and I found an interesting paper that analyzes populist communications of politicians on facebook <https://journals-sagepub-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/doi/full/10.1177/1940161218783836>
It is not very difficult to code the elements of a speech in order to identify populist claims. Nonetheless, as far as I know, this is a work that it is still being performed by humans, as the analysis of syntaxis is a very sophisticated operation. We could,  however, use the analysis that has been already done on speeches of famous leaders available in the database repository of Team Populism: <http://populism.byu.edu/Pages/Datat>
Our project could consist only on visualizing what is already there, to make people aware of the level of populism of their president/ prime minister

I appreciated Chapter 2 of Swartz's Programmable Web, in part because of having recently been able to understand the importance of his suggestions.  In a time where the likes of Squarespace or other website building providers exist, it can seem like a disconnect to most people why the guidance on designing URLs matters.   I myself, formerly having been one of those users!  Having now been on the development side of our agile sprint process, I can appreciate the importance of Swartz's guidance for the short term--(our sprint goal of having a working product website) and more broadly to the long term reach of an API.  As a newbie to thinking about how to structure something that will eventually be used by thousands, if not more people, and be plugged into other platforms or websites, the seemingly simple task of thinking of a URL structure seems much more complex and critical.  Swartz's emphasis on these types of fundamentals overlap with with Musser's (  <https://www.infoq.com/presentations/API-design-mistakes>) tips to API developers on how to make API's more user friendly.  Until hearing his presentation, I hadn't categorized API's as a user focused product.  I was more focused on the exciting potential they provided in being able to harness open source data towards set user/ product/or value goals.  However, it makes sense, within software and technology innovation, that a fundamental tool of how tech is better able to serve users (APIs) is also itself a user-focused product.  The focus on users (mostly, as it seems, developers) will lead to the further integration and usability of APIs as foundational components of more software innovation.  Extending agile principals to API's users enables the success of their hopes to build technology that focuses on users as well.

I agree with your opinion, I think that APIs are tools to foster innovation and tech specialization. In fact, I found this article from the New York Times, is quite interactive and it shows you to what degree different industries have benefited from APIs <https://www.nytimes.com/paidpost/ca-technologies/apis-the-building-blocks-of-the-app-economy.html>

I enjoyed reading Aaron Swartz’s book, I think he gives a humorous and easy-going introduction to the components and history of the internet. I had heard several times before the terms web2.0 and web3.0 but I was never completely sure what they meant. As I understand now, the web 2.0 is focused on the interactions and feedback from other users. Websites are developed and to a certain degree depend on the grading, commenting, editing, sharing and rearranging that users do while they visit the site. Web 3.0 is based on the capacity of machine systems to extract and use information taken from other websites, mainly meta data. In this order of ideas, it is interesting to conceive the abstraction level in which the internet currently operates.

APIs that suck video describes the problems and solutions of a poorly designed APIs. However, as with most of the API-related explanations, the video hasn't discussed much about why companies offering APIs provide such APIs, what data the companies collect when using these APIs, and what privacy or legal risks developers may face. Of course, this lecture seems to be targeted for developers, but developers need to pay more attention to privacy and legal issues as well. Developers are tend to concern mostly about development itself, and it's easy to miss such a problem. As such, I personally wish lectures and documents describing the API deal with above mentioned issues more.

The existence of public APIs and open data was responsible for most of the successful papers that got my public policy career started. In the beginning it was an openly downloadable Tableau viz of crime in the NYC Housing Authority hosted by the NY Daily News that saved me an extremely time-consuming FOIA request. Then it was NYC DOT's Vision Zero portal, which hosted open data on street treatments and traffic fatalities that allowed me to assess the impact of street safety treatments on timeseries data of traffic deaths. In a pre-Aaron Schwartz world, none of that would have been possible (even if he probably would have thought Tableau's products are shittier than the non-proprietary alternatives).

I agree with the earlier comments that the privacy implications of a lot of social network APIs still have to be worked out--for example Venmo's API can be queried for the social web of any public payments. I've heard that researchers have been able to heuristically identify user types and scenarios--e.g. drug dealers, sex workers, and "a breakup"--through ML and clustering. That's probably not what Aaron intended!

Completely agree with Nikhil. I just finished watching the Brexit HBO movie (which had some issues in terms of being factually accurate) but it was crazy how the Leave Campaign was able to leverage the APIs of social media platform like Facebook to collect data and then deploy extremely effective micro ad targeting to influence voters. This is part of a much broader debate about rules and regulations relating to campaigns, but I have to imagine part of the challenge for policymakers is such as complete lack of understanding of this ecosystem and how this all functions. It creates a situation where it is the wild west with politicians creating crap regulations that don't actually address the issue. It seems like there is just two completely distinct mindsets. One in the tech community about what is possible to continue to build a web that is more interactive and where people can leverage each others platforms and data, and the policy world where this has real world implications.

Picking up the conversation that was started a few days back on APIs--I find the notion of trying to make more websites accessible / editable (either through APIs or through the more direct type of editing that Aaron mentioned as being the "original web") to be intriguing.  I see some instances where this would be great--accessible APIs are popular with programmers for a reason, they democratize access to different data sets and make it easier to leverage existing products or commonly used functionality (in the case of Google or banking products, for example).  However, in light of our security conversation, I can't help but feel like too much access could be a dangerous thing.  Certainly allowing anybody to edit or access code for an essential website could be dangerous, but I'm curious about the security risks APIs might pose.  Were, for example, the pretty notable revelations that Facebook data was captured and shared by different applications a result of an easy to use and accessible API?

While I think I understand what an API is and does, I'm still having trouble visualizing it. As I understand it, the API is itself an application that allows someone to write an application that interacts with your product (be it a website or app). Perhaps developers look at APIs different than users. From the user perspective, how would one describe the function of an API? Do we know when we are interacting with an API or is it really just on the back end?

I wonder if this division of labor will help to make web-programming more into the mainstream as through the purchase of API services this would allow small-and -medium size companies to focus on certain aspects of web-programming and leverage on the skills of a third party. Specialization in the technology sector seems to be the wave of the future in all areas. Perhaps the days when one person had to know about everything and do all are gone.

Like Danny, I was also interested in the tension between privacy and open source data mentioned in Aaron Swartz's chapter on open source. While I understand that open source is necessary to ensure high standards of security and grant sufficient privacy, I am unsure about the balance between distributed access and maintaining personal privacy or intellectual property rights. While reflecting on this, I also thought about algorithmic transparency and how standardizing open source would be somewhat helpful for explaining machine learning and deep learning algorithms but again, the tension between maintaining rights over intellectual property versus allowing open access is a difficult one to resolve.

Aaron Swartz's defense of open source is smart, but his argument is flawed.  I found it particularly ironic when he went after Colin Doctorow for establishing a straw man and then proceeded to set up his own 'Semantic Web' strawman in the next paragraph.  Swartz, and others like him, are creating a false choice.  There is a place for open source, but so to is there a place for focused creation.  His argument against XML reveals this contradiction.  He states that XML is best used the way it was intended (a format for marking up textual arguments) or not at all, but is that not a semantic or ontological distinction?

I am in favor of open source technology in general.  However, I think it is not uncommon for technologists and coders to be naive at the implications of "democratizing" various aspects of society.  For instance, social networks could be viewed as open source.  Our journalism now comes from various places, sometimes anonymous ones.  For every success (wikipedia) there seem to be countless instances of "fake news" or other bad actors taking advantage of a democratized environment.  A credentialized marketplace had two advantages we would be well served to incorporate into open-source, if possible:  1) Expertise.  In order to publish something or to get it in front of people at a mass scale, an author or publisher had to be a peer reviewed expert.  These gatekeepers slow down processes and sometimes don't have incentives that are perfectly aligned with the general public, but they also provide a vital measure of quality control and sorting that the general public is incapable of.  2) Accountability.  If a product does damage, or is false or nefarious, credentialing provides both the culprit and repercussions (removal of credentials).  This is vital to keep open source arenas clear of bad actors.

Personally, when I think of an open source project, software such as Firefox, OpenOffice, and Android comes up first. It is interesting that Aaron Swartz mentioned Flickr or YouTube (which are web products) in the chapter on open source. According to "Why Attend - Open Source 101" (<http://opensource101.com/why-attend>), nearly 80-90% of today's software is either completely Open Source or contains elements of Open Source. However, open source projects often lose their directionality or quality if they do not have a clear lead in the project. Since the web is tend to be democracy oriented, I guess it is more likely that the web open source project does not have the clear lead compare to other open source projects. I wonder what would be the best model to avoid losing direction or quality for the web open source projects.

I found “making your data available as Open Knowledge” a little troubling to understand in terms of its benefits compared to “making your code available as free or open software.”  I can easily see the good side of opening up the code—as DoD explained this “an avalanche-like ‘virtuous cycle’,” contribution by users can make the software more capable. I benefitted from d3 examples that were provided to build our final projects around them. On the other hand, I felt that opening up data would only suit certain types of services such as government services and journalism. Opening up data through software could be useful in the circumstances where data is already meant to be public and the software serves as a good tool to transfer such information. However, if the nature of the data is not public—like the example Swartz’s used in facebook friends’ data—it simply does not make sense to make it open. Am I understanding the concept too narrowly?

I wonder how open sourcing can be used to restore and bolster faith in US governments & institutions. Some of the more progressive agencies are open sourcing their code, datasets, models, etc. I think this is great, but I wonder if more needs to be done because Github is not exactly accessible to the average person in the US. Schwartz cites Richard Stillman from MIT who had 4 basic freedoms associated with open source as a definition -- freedom to use for any purpose, see the source code, share with anyone, and release improvements. I wonder if open sourcing needs a 5th element regarding interpretability. It seems that this definition was made by a computer scientist for computer scientists, but as software starts running more of the average person's life, I think that we need to start aiming for software to be open to the average person as well. For governments and other institutions like Harvard, I think that accessibility should be looked at as some of the most important aspects of their digital governance, and it should be done in a way that doesn't assume you know how to use Github.

During Wednesday’s class, we briefly brought up the ethics of open source code and data, a topic that I would like to dive into in further detail. On one hand, by opening up code and data to all users, we have the ability to expand infinitely beyond our current knowledge base to build new platforms and services. It also allows us to crowdsource help with solving complex problems. At the same time, Dhrumil mentioned a really interesting case where a team’s code/data could be their main competitive advantage, and allowing open access to it on the web could inhibit their success. This brings up the issue of when it is alright to take the data from someone else’s website (with proper citation, of course) and when it is not. I’m not sure that we can trust all individuals to think through this distinction before acting. However, I also do not know how we can address this problem without limiting access to data for everyone. If anyone has any policy solutions to this, I would love to discuss.

From my own background, I know that economists at think tanks around DC have been working hard to make their data open source for exactly the same reasons as coders. One example is AEI’s open source policy center: <http://www.aei.org/feature/open-source-policy-center/>, which allows users to estimate the impacts of public policies. Their “tax brain” site also contains a GitHub account where users can make changes to AEI’s tax model for their own research. I think initiatives like this are one way to make public policy more interactive for the general public by allowing citizens to engage with the data, rather than assuming policy comes from a black box somewhere in DC. Open source policy work also allows the policymaking process to be more iterative, allowing citizens to design policy solutions to the problems they face from the bottom up, rather than waiting on lawmakers to enact change from the top down.

Just to kick things off here, I found some of the parting thoughts about peer-to-peer applications and the tension between privacy and open source in Aaron Schwartz’s open source chapter to be especially interesting. <#CFG6WKU9L|opensource> have you seen examples of a peer-to-peer application like the one he describes (in some cases I find this stuff hard to visualize without examples)? And do you understand what makes it so much harder to create a peer-to-peer app as compared to a web app? I can imagine that having user-customized apps communicate together without an online medium could throw unexpected errors or that the increased distribution of traffic could add complexity to existing networks, but I am not sure exactly what makes this model so much harder to create (besides political inertia and user competency of course).

I also found the point about having the freedom to download both the code and data from websites to be thought-provoking. I agree that we should be able to see and download our own data on websites (like Facebook), but I am having a hard time picturing what downloading other data you have access to would entail or how that could cause problems. He suggests that you should be able download all of your friends data on Facebook too (presumably stuff on their wall and visible things). That alone does not worry me, but I would think that such a change would also need to be communicated clearly to people so that they can adjust their behavior accordingly and I wonder where this philosophy of open code and open data would lead to a compromise of privacy even after people have an expectation that anything they post is truly public. For instance, having this distributed access would likely make it harder for propositions like the Right to be Forgotten laws in the EU to exist: <https://gdpr-info.eu/issues/right-to-be-forgotten/>.

Anyway, I am curious to hear other people’s thoughts on Schwartz’s vision for the internet in terms of its feasibility, tradeoffs, and to what extent his suggestions have come to pass.
